awd_titl_txt: CIF:Small: A Tensor-based Framework for Reliable Radio Cartography
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to devise an efficient framework for achieving radio frequency (RF) spectrum awareness through generating reliable and dynamic radio environment maps (REMs). This is a notable step towards the proliferation of realistic cognitive radio networks (CRNs), which enable spectrum sharing to alleviate the problem of spectrum scarcity. This efficient use of spectrum empowers ever-increasing applications and services with a great impact on national health, welfare, public safety, and economic growth. In addition, the developed data analysis tools provide a distinctive solution to high-dimensional signal sampling and processing, enabling further development in a wide range of applications, such as big data, Internet of Things, and wireless sensor networks, which can promote social and economic progress. This project integrates research and education through new course development and revisions, and involving underrepresented minorities, graduate, and undergraduate students in research.

This research bridges the gap between the theoretical research in tensor data analysis and wireless communications and networking to facilitate spectrum awareness. The investigators will develop a tensor-based framework to generate dynamic and reliable REMs that include RF signal power distribution over space, time and frequency. Tensor-based analysis facilitates the integration of the inherent properties and data structures that exist in CRNs as well as the prior knowledge of the behavior of the primary network. Bayesian and structure-based tensor decomposition is investigated, for which existence and uniqueness conditions are studied. The outcome of the decomposition is employed to obtain a model-based interpolation of sensor readings and to generate the REM. Corresponding to an REM, a reliability map will be created and utilized for optimal joint spectrum sensor and channel selection.

por.por_cntn:
The culmination of this project has yielded a pioneering framework aimed at achieving radio frequency (RF) spectrum awareness through the generation of dynamic and reliable Radio Environment Maps (REMs). This work offered a significant stride towards the realization of realistic Cognitive Radio Networks (CRNs), pivotal for mitigating spectrum scarcity issues by enabling efficient spectrum sharing.

To tackle the problem of REM generation, we leveraged different mathematical, signal processing, and machine learning tools such as compressive sensing, tensor decomposition, and deep learning. We devised a tensor-based framework for representing power spectral density over space, time, and frequency. This facilitates the incorporation of inherent properties and data structures that exist in cognitive radio networks (CRNs) as well as prior knowledge about primary users’ activities.

As a key enabler for generating radio environment maps, we further studied different model-driven localization techniques. Primary users’ localization is leveraged for estimating the radio usage map.  Further, we harnessed the power of advanced deep learning and machine learning techniques for the development of data-driven localization methodology leading to better radio cartography. As such we also studied the problem of robustness of deep learning models under noisy labels and anomalies.

Over the course of this project, one postdoc, five Ph.D. and several undergraduate and master students were trained. The Principal Investigator (PI) consistently refined the content of her courses each year, incorporating the latest research findings from this project. This provided a powerful venue for the dissemination of the latest research findings and exposing the students to new research directions. The mathematical and signal processing developments and the results from this project were published in leading journals and conference proceedings.
